section.text: Hi, thanks. There's a bit of an echo. I hope that it's not triggered by me. But Matt, maybe just first one on this notion of these mega projects, we're clearly seeing that show up in starts data -- construction starts data and it looks to be an increasing just percentage of just overall spend in these coming years. As we think about here in late October, looking into next year, is there a way to kind of size up how you sit from -- just from kind of an overall visibility standpoint in terms of what's -- obviously, you don't operate with a backlog, but just from kind of a project visibility or project backlog standpoint, is there a way to kind of size up how United is positioned as we go into '23 just from essentially work already in hand or forthcoming, if you can help on that at all.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tim Thein", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "1e67a027-4b04-4ad5-ae26-8ff10081130c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: Sure, Tim. So as far as the scale of it, we'll work on it as there some way that we can put a numerical value to it. But I can just tell you, in my 32 years of business, we have never seen these amount of mega projects, and specifically, in the infrastructure and commercial space on the books. The manufacturing is an added bonus that we really didn't expect to see where there's over $250 billion of funds already activated. So this is very tangible to us. But when I think about our positioning there, as you can imagine, we've been focused on national accounts for many, many years as a big part of our strategy, and these are the folks that are going to get the large share of this work. That, alongside with our broader set of services, we think positions us very well in this space.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "fe8f6253-6035-4e1d-9be5-ef3a26ba08d6", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: So we certainly expect to outpunch our weight of our overall industry market share with these customers and with these projects. And this is just another example of us thinking and believing strongly that the big book continue to get bigger and taking share. So that's the way I would think about it right now. And I don't know if you had any other thoughts.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "fe8f6253-6035-4e1d-9be5-ef3a26ba08d6", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Yeah, got it. Okay, thanks. And then your point on the leverage range and what a change from, say, a decade or so ago, and just in terms of how the balance sheet has evolved. But how are you thinking about the -- or the Board thinking about the two to three times target? Obviously, I'm sure you want to preserve some flexibility for M&A or other capital return opportunities. But obviously, with cash flows continuing to build, that potential for that to go even lower. So how are you and the Board thinking about that overall two to three times range? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tim Thein", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "622fa7ed-36dd-44b4-9201-11d14c998850", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: I'll let Ted speak to the leverage, but we don't at all see this as preventative from us being able to continue to invest in growth of the business, which is our first filter of what we'll do from a capital allocation perspective. Ted, please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "b4ba6ac1-eb26-4ffe-9828-73bde3b6e626", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Yeah. Tim, thanks for the question. Certainly, something we talk about frequently both as a management team and with the Board. And I guess, if you rewind back to 2019 when we introduced the new balance sheet strategy, I'd say key rationale was to ensure we had financial strength across the cycle, and where we sit today at 1.9, as you heard us talk about in the call, we absolutely feel very well-positioned from that standpoint. It gives us a lot of freedom and flexibility to run the business as we see fit.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Ted Grace", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "252fa135-f519-41f0-9119-449294bace6f", "speaker_title": "Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: We also said there was nothing religious about that low-end of two times that we were comfortable going below, to some degree. So again, kind of stockpile firepower, if you will. I think if we were to decide to live structurally in a lower ZIP code, choose the number you want, 1.5 to 2.5 as an example, at that point, I think we'd absolutely feel obligated to update the Street. But for the time being, we feel like this range and the flexibility we have around it remain appropriate.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "William Ted Grace", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "252fa135-f519-41f0-9119-449294bace6f", "speaker_title": "Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Okay, very good. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tim Thein", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "004681ae-b1ee-4b98-8ce0-34332b622db8", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: Thanks, Tim.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "42d87887-7b71-42ea-9dc6-c47a2db2460c", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Great. Thanks. Good morning. Just Ted, you mentioned that the capex increase is targeted at select cat classes, but it sounds like you guys have a pretty broadly positive view about a lot of end markets. Curious, why it's only in select cat classes then, if I heard that correctly?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steven Fisher", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "a5ad5b98-bf6d-46b2-bc10-e3c609b05a8f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: Hey, Steve, this is Matt. So let me put this in context this increase. We had orders similar to last year that because of some of the supply chain challenges, and you could imagine they would happen in more higher demand categories, right, where the OEMs are doing their best to keep up, but there's a lot of demand for these assets, they slipped all the way towards the end of the year here.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "f29fee47-8f15-4263-82de-af4dd11e4c0a", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: As we got to mid-October, we had a decision to make. Do we let this capex flow, and therefore, raise our guidance? Or do we cancel it and hope that we can get these high demand assets in the spring? We made the decision to let this flow, and for two reasons. Number one, the surety of supply because these are assets that have slipped quite a bit. And then secondly, we'll get these at '22 pricing instead at '23 pricing.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "f29fee47-8f15-4263-82de-af4dd11e4c0a", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: And we had some questions that people asked, wow, you were able to raise your capex, the supply chain must have really loosened up. It's actually quite the opposite. Because the supply chain is tight, we let these orders that have been delayed so long in the year flow-through because we really would rather get ahead of the curve here, and we do see 2023 is a growth year. So the selectiveness wasn't really our choice, it was as much because those are the assets that slipped as much as they did because of the high demand. Hopefully, that straightens that out for you, Steve.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "f29fee47-8f15-4263-82de-af4dd11e4c0a", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Yeah, that makes perfect sense. And then on the cold starts. I think you said you've done 25 cold starts with another 11 or so in the fourth quarter. I think that's a bit less than the $45 million [Phonetic] you had mentioned in Q2, I guess. Do I have those numbers right? And what's caused the reduction in that cold start number? Is that, again, just equipment availability? And then are you just planning to push those into 2023?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steven Fisher", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "94cbd9f5-5ba3-4610-bb5f-376a9fd1f668", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: Yes, Steve, I'll will double-check those numbers, but I think the goal is 40 to 45 [Phonetic] for the full year. I don't know if that's driving some confusion, but in terms of the pace at which we're opening cold starts in specialty, we're on track.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Ted Grace", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "9f704c16-4753-4477-abe4-4caa0fc41d24", "speaker_title": "Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Yes, if there is anything that would hold it up, it probably be more getting the right facilities and people really than fleet in those sectors, specifically in specialty.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "d32635fb-11e8-4df8-9e5c-c8cefec7b269", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Okay, thanks very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steven Fisher", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "98a72809-783b-4ebb-8ef9-f114521e3203", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: Great. Thanks. Good morning, everyone.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jerry Revich", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "e6328cea-68a3-49c9-92b7-285f09a06a97", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Good morning, Jerry.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "169bec3c-8957-46b7-9455-f07c4c0fbdff", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: I'm wondering if you could talk about how you're seeing performance at General Finance, just give us an update for those asset classes. And how do you view cyclicality, considering that's not an asset class that United had in prior cycles? Would love to see how you're thinking about the opportunity for penetration for that category. And similarly, are there any other specialty cross-selling opportunities that could be emerging for additional categories as a result of General Finance building out across your footprint?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jerry Revich", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "d9fa1d68-e75f-431f-b3f7-aba9dcac577b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Sure. And as we think about the GFN business and the teams that came with that, we had a thesis, if you recall, we announced that we feel that we can double this business in the next five years, and I can say that we're ahead of schedule on that. We're really getting robust growth out of this group. We're very, very pleased, not just with the team, but with the cross-sell opportunities to really -- our customer base is absorbed this like a drive's fun. So it's really been working well for us, and even ahead of the lofty planning that we had for it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "655f13f1-2adf-4b07-a3f0-8b72fda1156b", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: And as far as other products in that category, you can just imagine, like we did back in the day with pumps and like we did with tanks. Anytime we see something that's on a site, whether that be a plant or whether it'd be a project that our customers are running that we don't supply, we're looking for opportunities to add to the portfolio. And this was one that we've looked at for quite a few years until we finally found the right partner. So the tricky part for us is we're a believer that doing this through M&A and buying a big enough platform to make the offering broadly is real important to our national solution strategy towards our customers. So we'll continue to be on the lookout for it, Jerry, and hopefully, we'll find some other great opportunities like we did here with the GFN team.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "655f13f1-2adf-4b07-a3f0-8b72fda1156b", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Super. And just to shift gears, I know you folks look at scenario planning a lot, in COVID recession, margin degradation was really minimal in your business. Can you just talk about your scenarios for the next downturn, given the uncertainty in the market? How do you folks think about the leverage you would pull? And any updated thoughts on whether the level of performance we saw in that very different cycle is repeatable to what extent? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jerry Revich", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "93fd07b5-20f9-44dd-8c7e-763bf83b58af", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Jerry, I'll take that one. You're right, we do a lot of scenario analysis, and COVID certainly had unique dynamics. I think more than anything, it highlighted the flexibility of the business, both from a capex and an opex standpoint. And you asked about margin, so within opex, what you see is a lot of the businesses -- a lot of the costs, I should say, the cash costs that are really highly correlated to volume, and what that allows us to do is flex pretty rapidly and protect kind of those semi-variable costs that are labor. That's always going to be the goal in any kind of downside scenarios to take care of our people and retain that capacity, which is the hardest thing to replace, if ever had to. So that would be the play we'd run in virtually any scenario. And obviously, you look at different scenarios with different severity and different durations, but the playbook itself is very consistent across all that kind of modeling.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Ted Grace", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "b640c660-61fa-4b17-a457-3f21720cc170", "speaker_title": "Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Yeah, and I would agree, and the nice thing is when you do that in sourcing, utilizing our own labor, you're getting your highest costs out of there. So it worked really well in COVID, and Ted explained it well. It's something that we would -- definitely was a learning from COVID, but both sides of it. The reason we kept that capacity was for the ramp-up and it really gave us a great opportunity to move forward on the other side of whatever kind of cycle you deal.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "c2ddb785-9753-488d-bf13-fbe6653231be", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Appreciate the discussion, thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jerry Revich", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "ab462fc8-0b63-4385-bc8e-194d71b09bff", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "9b995bae-139c-4f9d-abd2-fc66b2e157af", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Hi, thank you very much. I was just curious, just trying to think about '23, not looking for exact guidance, just trying to think through the growth drivers. Where are your fleet is going to end the year? If we just assume the fleet doesn't grow at all, the fleet will be on average about 5% bigger than it was in '22. So when we think of the drivers for '23, nothing inorganic, but when we think about further expansion of the fleet, rate and you, curious, can you just give us some sense of where do you still see room for growth, be it contracts coming due that -- or due for a price increase, kind of where you see rates, just for a sense, I'm not trying to get -- just trying to get some prioritization here of how do we grow across those three major buckets as we sit here today?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Raso", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "6d19fd69-0604-4677-831e-67f1b7171bff", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Sure, David. So to your point, we'll have some natural carryover fleet growth and then adds whatever number once we get through our planning process that we'll communicate in January, how much fleet we put on top of that for growth capex versus maintenance capital, and then think about the carryover we'll have in fleet productivity, although we don't expect fleet productivity stay in these very frothy double-digit ranges, mostly due to comps when we think about that we'll have some continued fleet productivity well above our hurdle rate.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "3bf4dad5-55f5-461c-85fb-fd7c2e8e44d4", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: So we really think that -- remember, that's the year-over-year metrics, many times your fleet productivity is over that 1.5% hurdle rate, you're growing the business faster, you're growing the revenues faster than you're growing your fleet, which is going to have accretive value to the margins and flow-through. And we foresee both of those continuing to happen.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "3bf4dad5-55f5-461c-85fb-fd7c2e8e44d4", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: The level -- the wild card will be how much and that's what we're working through in the planning process and along with our partners to see what the capital situation could be, and all will be meeting the demand environment and be very flexible, but we do see '23 as a growth year, to your point, because some of the natural carryovers that we're bringing into the year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "3bf4dad5-55f5-461c-85fb-fd7c2e8e44d4", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: When it comes to the rate momentum, do we see further rate increases for '23? Again, I know you don't like speaking about exact rates, I'm not looking for a percentage. But just from where we sit today, there is some carryover, of course, but how are you thinking about rate -- the ability to raise rate to start '23?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Raso", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "2a7c9459-8e8e-4ae5-8b49-664db6e2cbe9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: So if I think about the last few years, not just this year, and the discipline that's been in the industry, we are all having cost of goods increase. So -- and our customers are too, so they understand that. So there is a real focus on everybody understanding that we have to keep it balanced with that inflation from a rate perspective, and we're going to continue to do our part in that as a leader, and I'm very pleased to see that the industry is doing the same. So we would expect that. How much? We'll see. But we do expect the environment for 2023 to continue to be conducive to driving, specifically that component of the fleet productivity.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "26b2d8e3-0312-40df-8b1e-fcd9674e7c68", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: All right, thank you very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Raso", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "c82a0052-b60d-43d6-81ba-2058d6d38e00", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Thank you, Dave.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "add67521-fa6c-4547-a76f-22d8fd9cc058", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Hey, guys, good morning. Hey, Matt, I just wanted to go back to your pull-forward capex comment. I mean, I'm just trying to tie that together. So should -- I'm not looking for '23 guidance, but should we assume or should we think about that as kind of being a governor on 2023 gross capex growth if you're "pulling some of that forward"? And then I guess my follow-up question is, should we expect used equipment sales to really pickup next year as well? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Seth Weber", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "08ae00ca-cc7d-488d-959b-cd9ef5eeac5b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Sure. So two points to that. As far as a governor on growth, would you see it as a net where we end up in capex planning, absolutely, and we'll flex that as always with demand. What this really does is let us not have to worry about how quick the supply and demand pipeline meet each other by getting a little bit of head start on these assets that were tougher to get this year. So that's number one. So there'll be some netting effect once we finish our planning process, but because we will have it in hand already hopefully, it will almost be part of the planning process. So we'll give that new number to everybody.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "29aa6063-5a2c-4e1e-8806-83ea4de746a5", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: As far as the used sales, we would as long as the supply-demand can be at appropriate level as opposed to a little -- almost too imbalance this year and we had to hold onto fleet, because we frankly couldn't sell because it was on rent. We hope to get to more normalized fleet rotation next year. And the kind of used sales that you would have seen pre-COVID and what we hope to get to that kind of cadence in used sales. And first -- fourth quarter and first quarter is usually are the heaviest months and we'd expect that to continue on as we sit here today.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "29aa6063-5a2c-4e1e-8806-83ea4de746a5", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Okay, that's perfect. Thank you. And then just maybe as a follow-up. Matt, in prior periods of rising interest rates and stuff, do you typically see the IRCs being less able to buy fleet? Are you hearing anything about the IRCs being more just restricted here? Or do you feel like the capex that's coming into the market just pretty much across the board?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Seth Weber", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "27aec10f-dc91-4948-88a5-efb0977b9437", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: I think everybody across the board has an opportunity to grow, and I think most strong solid companies that have the financial wherewithal to do that are doing that. As you can imagine, the OEMs are going to sell-out their inventory anyway, so they're probably being pretty disciplined about who they sell to. With that being said, I don't want to paint or homogenize the whole independent group but some are better capitalized than others. And those that aren't well capitalized.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "60ce1d39-dee3-4277-888a-e938790f2817", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: I've got to imagine, the inflationary environment is going to be a challenge for them. For us, and specifically the national, this is one of the reasons why we think this environment will continue to drive the big is getting bigger, so to speak, and put a value on scale to continue to be able to overcome whatever challenges the economy for you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "60ce1d39-dee3-4277-888a-e938790f2817", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Got it. Makes sense, guys. Okay, thank you. Appreciate it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Seth Weber", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "bb10e59f-b3f4-4f9e-a82a-802d05e4f2fc", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Thanks, Seth.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "29b5e7c8-b48a-4ba7-b85f-625a800c08df", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Hey, thanks. Good morning, everybody.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rob Wertheimer", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "a06a70c8-2bb8-44cb-a901-e311792ef963", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Melius Research"}

section.text: Hey, Rob.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "86be17e4-0fd2-43ae-9eb1-fc7c07d4a3d7", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: So I wanted to ask on the question that Matt touched on earlier. You guys -- on mega projects, you guys have spent a lot of years focusing on national accounts and serving big clients, the market shifting towards big projects in a way that we maybe have never seen before. And I wondered if you'd be willing to give like a two-minute teaching on what you've done, what market share looks like in a big project, service by a big national contractor who can provide the capabilities, what the capabilities are, and if you wanted to get tangible, I assume your market share at something like [Indecipherable] was higher than 15%. Just wonder if you can give us any help on that. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rob Wertheimer", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "7fe7a5b4-46aa-4bbb-aa4f-6f1473e86bec", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Melius Research"}

section.text: Yeah, when you think about large projects, right, whether -- wherever you draw the line of mega, but really any kind of project of scale, it's going to need multiple products. This is one of the reasons why we think a very broad offering is important because one of the things that people don't necessarily think about is the security and safety of a site is very important to construction managers. They're held responsible and held accountable to that security and safety, and obviously, if you don't have 20 different suppliers running around supporting project, you have a little bit more consistency.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "ec85b772-5b91-4179-a37a-44998fc38fd4", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: I also think we feel like we lead strongly with safety, but I think this is an area where the larger companies that can invest in tools, invest -- and have a focused culturally on safety are at a competitive advantage. As far as what share, it's going to depend on each project. But you can imagine that the players that can serve most of the needs are the ones that are going to be in the best position. And I don't want to get into market share on that because it varies by project, there's very few sole-source projects as opposed to plant work, but you may have a sole-source contract that you bid for. So there'll be multiple people on a project, and the ones that do the better job are going to get a better share once they prove it to the customer.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "ec85b772-5b91-4179-a37a-44998fc38fd4", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Thank you. And if you could just adding to that discussion briefly technology, you touched on it earlier. I know you've invested a lot in tech. Do big projects use it a lot more aggressively? You mentioned a couple of margins with productivity and so forth. What is most attractive to big projects on the tech front? And I will stop there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rob Wertheimer", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "a87d0db9-55bf-4a77-99fa-23e609622152", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Melius Research"}

section.text: Sure, Rob. Thanks for the opportunity to mention. The visibility that we can get then through our connected assets, so we have over 250,000 assets that have telematics on it, and that in itself is a big investment that reaped some rewards for us and for our customers, so that we can give them real-time data, whether that's location, utilization, fuel alerts. there's a lot of stuff that's unique to that investment. And think about a large complex project, that visibility, that -- the people who are in-charge of leading that project really gives them help in running a more efficient process and bringing more money to the bottom line, which is their job, right? Running the job at the appropriate cost levels and productivity. So rental has always been about driving safety and productivity, and I would say, the connected job site and the data that we can bring to it through our tools just up the ante on driving better productivity.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "5b42f2c7-4225-4b5b-96cf-a3c9f9523e13", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rob Wertheimer", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "a27f8222-7f56-4877-8b15-efb3ebcc0589", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Melius Research"}

section.text: Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "3329ae47-b172-4fd4-8e7e-b38ebca2093a", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Hey, morning, guys.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ken Newman", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "e8b9d30b-d331-4421-b968-f932ca193866", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KeyBanc Capital Markets"}

section.text: Morning, Ken.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "3b40c972-20eb-4537-941c-f29ec3e9a442", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Maybe I missed it, but I think you talked a little bit about strong customer sentiment. Just any color on how your internal customer survey is trending this quarter relative to last quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ken Newman", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "5d8221a2-479e-4bf3-bc54-a2ecd1662929", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KeyBanc Capital Markets"}

section.text: Yeah, Kevin, good question. Simply, it's trended remarkably in line. It's really hasn't been any deviation in our customer optimism looking forward. And as a reminder to everybody else, that's something we do as part of our Net Promoter Scores, and we ask them on a forward 12-month basis as they feel about the revenue prospects.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Ted Grace", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "2a1c2f89-8c78-40aa-a69d-78527c187678", "speaker_title": "Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Got it. That's very helpful.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ken Newman", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "41a4d44a-54c4-4b99-acc8-5b857da35d0e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KeyBanc Capital Markets"}

section.text: And I guess, the other thing I would add is, it's very -- sorry, also very consistent with the feedback we get from the field. So we're constantly making sure that those two data points, if you will, do align. And the good news is they continue to align.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "6c9c569e-4daa-49ad-a956-b76a0f788728", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Yeah, makes sense. And then for my follow-up, this might be a bit of a harder question to answer. But just given how tight the fleet is and how tight supply chain has been, is there any idea that -- just how much revenue opportunities you had to pass on because you didn't have the fleet that you wanted? Or any idea of whether or not you think all of that fleet would have been on rent as soon as they hit?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ken Newman", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "deec3a9c-17c7-4cf3-880f-6f174f74a0bc", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KeyBanc Capital Markets"}

section.text: Yeah, certainly when the market is running as high it as it has this year and you have the supply-demand dynamic we had, I got to imagine that peak season everyone's missing a little bit of business, and as part of it customers learned to plan better, part of it customers didn't turn in fleet as quickly, some even move to job to job.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "3ecde130-4289-4e48-b9d8-ea44b2a6657f", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: So with our key accounts and the people that we're strategically aligned with and focused on, we got through it all. But on the outside of that, the transactional business, we absolutely going to put more fleet to work. We have to stay very focused on prioritizing our key accounts and making sure we took care of our key relationships and supported them in a manner they expect to be in United Rentals. So we should certainly lost some, hard to quantify, but net-net, we're very pleased with the 20% growth so won't get too far out there on that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "3ecde130-4289-4e48-b9d8-ea44b2a6657f", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Appreciate it. Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ken Newman", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "f69b3f91-3d4c-4394-8afc-3ace2bd3766d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KeyBanc Capital Markets"}

section.text: Thanks, Ken.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "d24e13b3-d226-4a5f-874c-91532b5c583e", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Great. Good morning, guys. Thank you for taking my question. A lot of discussion about these mega projects, and some of the tailwinds from infrastructure, etc. I'm just trying to kind of get a sense of how you think about sizing that, I mean, how much of your business in two or three years when these things are really ramped up, how much of it comes from those types of projects?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Volkmann", "section_number": 60, "uuid": "19e5b559-f08c-4032-b458-8ea67b2cb12b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: Steve, it's a good question. It's certainly hard to say how much of the total business comes from those opportunities or how much of the total business is driven by those, but certainly, we can dimensionalize what those numbers look like in the absolute. So if you look at infrastructure, as an example, it's nominally $550 billion over five years. So if you just add, it's $110 billion on an annualized basis, that's in the context of the total non-res construction market, but that's $800 billion.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Ted Grace", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "70016a4f-3933-4686-a396-c9422fac32ce", "speaker_title": "Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: And within that, the public piece is probably $340 billion. So it's quite meaningful, right? You would say, $100 billion in the $800 billion market is 12% tailwind, all else equal. And then you start thinking about some of the other programs, IRA, it's harder to dimensionalize, you've got $370 billion of tax credits to get levered, right? So the intended spending there is substantially larger than that, probably longer timeframe admittedly, but that same dimensionalization, $800 billion of total non-res, $340 billion of public non-res.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "William Ted Grace", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "70016a4f-3933-4686-a396-c9422fac32ce", "speaker_title": "Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: If you look at some of the stuff more in the private domain, semi as an example, we're tracking $200 billion to $250 billion of projects or intended spend the companies have announced in the US. So again, Q2 is the denominator, but if you think it's over five or 10 years, that's in the context of a private non-res market that's about $470 billion. So there again, it's quite substantial. Autos would be another one. These numbers are harder to come by, but we think you can pretty confidently underwrite hundreds of billions of dollars of total investment in North America by the OEMs and all their supply chain partners, which again, is in that context of $800 billion of total non-res, call, $500 billion of private non-res.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "William Ted Grace", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "70016a4f-3933-4686-a396-c9422fac32ce", "speaker_title": "Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Energy is another one tough to dimensionalize, but I think we're all aware of what's going to drive US natural gas exports over the next many years and that'll be another one. So when you think about those in the context of what the existing market is, there are going to be a really big tailwinds. In terms of what that traction is looking out three, five, 10 years, it's much harder to say, but suffice to say, there'll be meaningful contributors. Does that help?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "William Ted Grace", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "70016a4f-3933-4686-a396-c9422fac32ce", "speaker_title": "Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Yeah, no, that's great. You guys have definitely thought that through. Appreciate it. Maybe my follow-up, a little bit closer term, maybe more of a Ted question. I'm trying to think about how to think about SG&A in 2023 and I'm guessing that there's a fair amount of kind of incentive comp of various types that's in there that probably resets and maybe doesn't recur in 2023. Just any way to think about those trends.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Volkmann", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "63e72fa0-c7bd-45ad-aa6c-6b8d8a20acb9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: Yeah, too early to get into the details about the headwinds or the tailwinds, I should say, from prospectively incentive comp reset, but certainly, you can hear our tone on growth and we've certainly expect the leverage, the nature of SG&A, again, in 2023, that will obviously be embedded within our guidance we give, which is EBITDA, as you know, so it's kind of below the line, if you well. But suffice to say, we would look to get another year of healthy leverage on those costs.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Ted Grace", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "4fb450de-7557-4afd-9c62-34fb321a5551", "speaker_title": "Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Okay. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Volkmann", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "7a1a017c-27ee-44cd-ad9b-068ccb605939", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: Thanks, Steve.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Ted Grace", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "e0012585-112f-43dd-bfa9-0411483e0d5e", "speaker_title": "Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer at United Rentals"}

section.text: Thank you, operator, and thanks everyone for joining the call. We're very proud to deliver such top strong profitable growth in our busiest season, but now we've got to look forward. We're deep into the planning process for '23. So stay tuned for our new guidance on the January call. And until then, if you have any questions, feel free to reach out to Ted any time and he'll be very helpful. So with that, operator, please end the call.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matthew J. Flannery", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "295f482c-af1d-45eb-aa94-02dcc40b484c", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at United Rentals"}

title: Q&A for URI (United Rentals) on 10/27/22 11:00 AM ET
